name: Human Rights
title: 8 weeks under siege in Minnesota
authors: Max Nesterak, Brian Martucci, Atra Mohamed, J. Patrick Coolican
description:
A week later, federal immigration agents shot a second person after a case of apparent mistaken identity, setting off clashes between law enforcement and protesters.
ProPublica reported in October — months before Operation Metro Surge in Minnesota — that immigration agents have detained more than 170 U.S. citizens.
Journalists have witnessed federal immigration agents check random non-white people’s documents outside big box stores, electric vehicle charging stations and bus stops.
In St. Paul, federal agents briefly pulled over two unmarked contract vans carrying students and staff to school in mid-January.
ICE agents slipping on ice has become its own genre on social media and a source of schadenfreude for many opposed to their presence.
text:
Frank has a hard time explaining to his 8-year-old daughter why they rarely leave their home in the Twin Cities. Why she can’t go to school, and why he can’t work.

“The only thing we tell her is that soon everything will be over. Everything will be over soon, and she’ll go back to school like before,” Frank said in Spanish.

The truth is, no one knows when the federal siege will end. It may not be soon.

U.S. Border Patrol Commander Gregory Bovino, who calls his officers “troops,” said “this mission is ongoing until there are no more of those criminal illegal aliens roaming the streets.”

Frank — who asked that he be identified only by his nickname to protect his identity — is originally from Mexico but has lived in the United States for more than a decade.

He has a pending application for what’s known as a U visa, which are available to victims of human trafficking, domestic abuse and other serious crimes, so they can cooperate with law enforcement without the fear of being deported.

The Trump administration has pushed to eject U visa applicants, which is why Frank’s lawyer has advised him to keep a low profile. Other immigrants in similar situations have been detained and deported, all while following the rules.

Frank knows a dozen people who’ve been deported — several in just the past couple weeks, including a co-worker on a construction job site.

His kids, three of whom are U.S. citizens, switched to online school. He stopped going to work, and he and his wife never leave the house together, lest they both be detained and separated from their children.

Frank, who has no criminal record save a couple traffic tickets, is the main breadwinner for his family. They’ve been able to live off savings, although he recently had to ask his mother in Mexico for help.

“We still don’t have enough, but we have a little bit to survive on,” he said.

‘Reckoning & Retribution’

The aggressive campaign of sweeping up immigrants has driven tens of thousands of people like Frank into hiding.

The Trump administration claims they are targeting the “worst of the worst” criminals in the country illegally in the “largest DHS operation ever” with some 3,000 federal agents in Minnesota.

Their ranks far surpass the several hundred agents sent to the Chicago area despite Minnesota having a much smaller population and far fewer immigrants without permanent legal status. Pew Research estimates 130,000 out of Minnesota’s roughly 6 million residents are undocumented, a relatively small percentage compared to states like Texas and Florida — contrary to Vice President JD Vance’s recent claim that Minneapolis has the “highest concentration of people who have violated our immigration laws.”

Launched in December under the stated goal of combating Medicaid fraud, the operation followed a high-profile state and federal investigation into social services fraud that involved mostly Somali American defendants. The case drew years of local media attention before being amplified by right-wing outlets and, eventually, by the president himself.

“Do the people of Minnesota really want to live in a community in which their are thousands of already convicted murderers, drug dealers and addicts, rapists, violent released and escaped prisoners, dangerous people from foreign mental institutions and insane asylums, and other deadly criminals too dangerous to even mention,” Trump posted to Truth Social on Jan. 13, promising the day of “RECKONING & RETRIBUTION IS COMING!”

The Department of Homeland Security says it’s arrested some 3,000 undocumented criminals in Minnesota since December — and 10,000 in the past year — although the figures strain credulity and the agency hasn’t provided a full list of who those people are.

Instead, DHS has periodically released curated lists of mug shots including many of those who were already in custody in state prisons.

The operation has ignited fierce resistance from residents and Democratic officials that’s grown into a crescendo since an ICE officer shot and killed Renee Good, a 37-year-old unarmed woman, in her car in south Minneapolis. Many Minnesotans grew further outraged when the Department of Homeland Security called her a “domestic terrorist,” while the U.S. Department of Justice yanked local investigators off the case. A week later, federal immigration agents shot a second person after a case of apparent mistaken identity, setting off clashes between law enforcement and protesters.

Gov. Tim Walz, whose office was subpoenaed by the feds for documents related to state immigration enforcement, appealed directly to Trump and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem to “end this occupation,” as has virtually every elected Democrat in the state including Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey whose appeal was, “get the f*ck out.”

Neither has any influence with the Trump administration besides, and Walz has become a lame duck since announcing early this month he won’t run for a third term.

As Democrats wait for proven vote-getter Sen. Amy Klobuchar to announce a run governor, the resistance to Trump’s siege has not come from politicians but from everyday Minnesotans — practiced in protest since even before the police murder of George Floyd — using a decentralized but well-organized system for spotting and harassing federal officers and giving aid to people who need it.

Minnesotans have reacted with an unbending resistance befitting people who are accustomed to withstanding the bitter cold. The state’s Midwestern progressivism, civic activism, volunteerism and tight familial and social networks serve as crucial infrastructure of the rampart against the federal presence.

Assaults on citizens

Each day brings a new news story about a lawful resident being handcuffed, sometimes beaten, and whisked away in an unmarked vehicle, unable to reach family members.

A Minnesota-born, Somali-American woman with no criminal record was shoved to the ground by ICE agents outside her apartment in St. Paul and called a racial slur on a Wednesday morning.

Nasra Ahmed, 23, says even though she showed agents her ID, she was detained for two days, including being shackled in a hospital while undergoing an MRI after suffering an apparent stress-induced seizure.

Just a few days later, at least eight masked federal agents broke down the door of a U.S. citizen with no criminal history in East St. Paul and arrested him at gunpoint in front of his 5-year-old grandson. (The Associated Press reported this week that “federal immigration officers are asserting sweeping power to forcibly enter people’s homes without a judge’s warrant.”)

Video taken by a neighbor show officers leading the man, ChongLy Scott Thao, outside in 10-degree weather wearing only a pair of blue boxer briefs, white crocs and a plaid blanket draped over his shoulders. He was detained for about an hour in a vehicle before agents dropped him back off at home.

DHS spokeswoman Tricia McLaughlin said he matched the description of two men with criminal convictions at Thao’s address, but Thao hardly looks like either of them, save for being Asian, and said he doesn’t know either man. One of the men turned out to have been in prison since 2024.

ProPublica reported in October — months before Operation Metro Surge in Minnesota — that immigration agents have detained more than 170 U.S. citizens.

Federal agents are also targeting the roughly 5,600 refugees in Minnesota who have yet to receive permanent residency as part of “Operation PARRIS” — Post-Adminision Refugee Reverification and Integrity Strengthening. It has entailed arresting refugees with no criminal records who are complying with the federal government’s rigorous screening process including more than a dozen health and background checks.

Countless other lawful residents have been stopped and asked to show identification just on the suspicion of looking like an immigrant.

“In every situation, we’re doing targeted enforcement,” Noem said when asked why Americans are being asked on the street to prove their citizenship. “If we are on a target and doing an operation, there may be individuals surrounding that criminal that we may be asking who they are.”

Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison alleged federal agents are racially profiling people — which DHS denies — in a lawsuit filed with the cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul seeking to end the operation.

Evidence supporting the allegation abounds.

Journalists have witnessed federal immigration agents check random non-white people’s documents outside big box stores, electric vehicle charging stations and bus stops. Agents even demanded the papers of a Latino U.S. citizen whom they rear-ended.

Brooklyn Park Police Chief Mark Bruley said while he has worked well with ICE in the past, his department is now receiving “endless complaints about civil rights violations” including from members of his own police force who aren’t white.

Federal agents boxed in one of his officers — a U.S. citizen — while she was off-duty and demanded to see her papers, Bruley said during a news conference with other local law enforcement leaders. The agents had their guns drawn and knocked the off-duty officer’s phone out of her hand, leaving only after she identified herself as a police officer — without comment or apology.

“Our officers know what the Constitution is. They know what right and wrong is. And they know when people are being targeted. And that’s what they were,” Brule said.

Minneapolis Police Chief Brian O’Hara told the New York Times that federal agents have stopped police officers’ family members, though “they’re not stopping family members of folks who are Norwegian or Irish.”

Many people of color in the Twin Cities now grab their passports before leaving the house — a previously unthinkable and unacceptable necessity of life in the modern United States.

The aggressive papers checks, which a court may very well determine are unconstitutional, are driven by a perverse incentive structure that rewards officers for the number of arrests they make, even if the people they detain are later released, the Wall Street Journal reported.

Pervasive fear

The terror the federal occupation is inflicting on immigrants — regardless of their legal status — is apparent in missed school days, doctors appointments and work shifts.

Schools, hospitals and churches have traditionally been off-limits to immigration agents, but Trump lifted the restrictions on immigration enforcement actions at sensitive locations that provide essential services in one of the first immigration policy directives of his second term.

Minneapolis Public Schools canceled school for two days after federal agents came to the high school that houses the Spanish immersion program during dismissal, hours after an ICE agent killed Good. They tackled people, handcuffed two staff members and released chemical irritants outside the school. A Border Patrol spokesperson told KARE 11 the skirmish happened after bystanders interfered with federal agents making an arrest next to the school.

In St. Paul, federal agents briefly pulled over two unmarked contract vans carrying students and staff to school in mid-January. The stops ended without incident but nevertheless frightened students and parents.

In Columbia Heights, a Minneapolis suburb, school officials say federal agents have detained four students in two weeks, including a 5-year-old boy and his father after returning home from school and a 10-year-old and her mother on the way to school.

“ICE agents have been roaming our neighborhoods, circling our schools, following our buses, coming into our parking lots and taking our children,” Zena Stenvik, the Columbia Heights Public School District superintendent, said at a news conference on Wednesday.

School districts across the Twin Cities metro have noted a drop in attendance from students from Latino and other immigrant families. In St. Paul, at least one-fourth of students from Spanish-speaking homes have missed every day of school since Dec. 12.

Minneapolis and St. Paul public schools have both responded by offering virtual learning options for students who don’t feel safe coming to school. It’s a better option than no school at all, and yet students still haven’t recovered from pandemic-era learning loss.

Medical providers have also reported many of their immigrant patients have stopped showing up to appointments. Diabetics are rationing insulin. Jaundiced babies are missing treatment. Mothers are laboring in hiding.

ICE agents have entered hospitals, including Hennepin County Medical Center, the largest safety-net hospital in Minnesota, without judicial warrants to guard detainees needing medical care around the clock over the objections of medical staff.

One is Alberto Castaneda Mondragon, who suffered a life-threatening brain injury shortly after being detained by ICE, according to a lawsuit filed on his behalf. He doesn’t remember how he was injured and has been medically sedated since being hospitalized, but an agent told medical staff “he got his sh*t rocked,” according to the lawsuit.

ICE’s presence has sent a chilling effect throughout the hospital — on both patients and staff.

Medical staff, elected officials and immigrant rights activists held a news conference decrying ICE’s presence in the hospital in early January, and two days later DHS subpoenaed the hospital’s employment records to audit workers’ employment eligibility, which one Hennepin County commissioner called “retaliatory.”

Immigration lawyers have reported a surge in similar audits at businesses across the Twin Cities — including a St. Paul toy store with a handful of part-time employees — making the federal siege personally painful for business owners who might otherwise be immune from immigration operations.

Businesses that rely on immigrant workers — and customers — across the economy are all feeling the effects of the siege.

A new underground relief network

The siege on Minnesota has ignited a relief effort on the scale of a natural disaster response, albeit under the glaring eyes of the federal government.

Churches, schools and coffee shops have become pop-up collection centers for food and other necessities that are distributed to immigrant homes.

A trans-owned sex toy store in Minneapolis called Smitten Kitten has become one of the major distribution centers, with boxes of Kleenex and Kraft Mac and Cheese and Campbell’s soup piled up next to displays of leather harnesses and wooden paddles.

Anne Lehman has been working around the clock since putting out the call for donations on Jan. 10, directing volunteers and a steady flow of donations.

Lehman wears hoop earrings with 3D-printed whistles that people drop off by the bagful every couple days to arm observers with what’s become the signature symbol of resistance. One whistle says “Go home passport bro” and the other “beta male repellant” — they’ve gotten a fair amount of use, too.

“We all know that ICE is f*cking dweebs. They’re just cosplaying their ‘Call of Duty’ game, but they’re also actively terrorizing and traumatizing my city,” Lehman said.

People are welcome to come pick up donations right from the store, or Lehman sends it on to larger collection sites at churches and trusts it eventually makes it to people in need.

They don’t track where all the food and diapers and tubes of toothpaste go, which adds a layer of security for the people they’re trying to help.

Lehman says Smitten Kitten has gotten the attention of federal agents, and fears if they started making deliveries from the store they could unintentionally lead immigration agents to vulnerable families.

Eventually the supplies end up with families like Raquel’s.

Raquel and her husband, Jesus, have lived in the United States for more than 20 years. She works as a house cleaner, he as a roofer. They own a home in the northern suburbs where they’re raising their two kids.

But their deeply rooted lives in Minnesota became suddenly precarious under the Trump administration and his focus on Minnesota. Raquel and Jesus — who were granted anonymity to protect their identities — have had pending U visa applications for several years.

She stopped going to work in the cities, where ICE has focused much of their attention. It’s been a hit financially, although some of her clients have continued to pay her to help make ends meet. One brings her groceries.

But the suburbs aren’t free from ICE either. Her best friend’s brother was just deported with his son while doing construction work in the suburbs.

While her kids are still going to school, she stopped taking them to the mall or out to eat. She’s had to instruct them not to answer the door, and while she and her husband never leave together.

“Because in case we both get detained, my kids are at risk to be alone,” Raquel said. “We don’t have family here.”

Her boss has let her use her vehicle, since ICE can pull up vehicle registrations and appears to be targeting people with Hispanic last names. Her husband checks ICE activity online crowdsourced by an army of volunteer observers to try to avoid places where they’re active.

“We spend more on gas but that doesn’t matter to stay safe,” he said.

A growing resistance

Twin Cities residents have been turning out every day to monitor ICE activities. Car horns and whistles have become a constant in parts of the cities, alerting immigrants to lock their doors and citizens to come out and film.

Walz has encouraged Minnesotans to keep their phones handy to record any federal activity, creating a “database of atrocities” to serve as evidence in future prosecutions.

Bystanders have documented numerous instances of federal agents brutalizing people, including a border patrol agent kneeing a man in the face several times while others hold him down.

Some residents have taken to driving around the metro looking for ICE vehicles — tinted windows and out-of-state plates, usually — and then tailing them to observe, but also to distract them and slow them down.

“The more time they’re trying to get away from us, the less time they’re spending searching for people to abduct,” one patroller, Patty O’Keefe, told the Reformer.

Neighborhood group chats dedicated to tracking ICE movements regularly reach capacity at 1,000 members, while a group that trains people to be ICE watchers is looking for larger venues.

It’s become a cat and mouse game, but with the roles frequently changing.

Federal agents, in an effort to evade observers, have taken to switching the license plates on their vehicles — a crime in Minnesota, the state Department of Public Safety reminded Noem in a letter.

Sometimes they’ll lead the observers to their own homes — apparently using a law enforcement database to connect license plate numbers to addresses in an effort to intimidate observers.

They’ve also threatened and detained people for following them. O’Keefe was recently dragged from her car with another observer, Brandon Sigüenza, and detained for around eight hours before being released without charges.

Federal agents have responded to crowds of observers and hecklers with aggressive force — tackling people, spraying them in the face with chemical irritants and deploying enough tear gas to cause coughing fits in a several block radius.

High-ranking leaders on the ground have not just encouraged these tactics, but participated in them. Bovino, the Border Patrol commander, threw a can of gas in a melee that broke out when a crowd formed around a federal convoy driving slowly through a residential neighborhood in Minneapolis.

The show of force came just hours after the 8th Circuit Court of Appeals reversed a lower court judge’s ruling in a case brought by the ACLU that sought to stop federal agents from detaining and tear gassing people engaged in peaceful protest or observation.

Resistance to ICE has gone mainstream, at least in the core cities, where businesses have plastered signs telling federal agents they’re not welcome without a judicial warrant. Scores of unions, businesses and organizations are expected to participate in a general strike on Friday.

Homeland Security posted on social media that Border Patrol agents have been struggling to find a place to go to the bathroom in Minneapolis because at each gas station they are turned away or met with groups of angry residents.

The weather hasn’t cooperated either. A steady accumulation of snow has thawed and refrozen several times as temperatures yo-yoed between unusually balmy 40s and bonechilling sub-zeros, glazing sidewalks and city streets with ice.

Federal agents have beached their SUVs and cars in slush and snowbanks across the metro, often having to call in back-up to be pushed free.

ICE agents slipping on ice has become its own genre on social media and a source of schadenfreude for many opposed to their presence.

One particularly viral moment was captured from several angles by bystanders: a Border Patrol agent in a black balaclava runs down the street before hitting a patch of ice that sends both feet skywards before he lands on his back. Observers can be seen jumping in celebration as he turns around and jogs back to his unmarked black Chevrolet Suburban.

The clip was set to praise music, mixed in ice-on-ICE compilations, and played multiple times to a cheering audience of Saturday Night Live.

Every day, protesters line the street outside the Whipple Federal Building in Minneapolis, which briefly appeared on a list of federal buildings to be sold last year during Trump’s DOGE era and is now serving as home base for Operation Metro Surge. The office building, which houses offices for DHS, Veterans Affairs, and Fish and Wildlife Services, now serves as a short-term detention center for immigrants and protesters, who’ve described sordid, overcrowded conditions.

On a recent Saturday, several hundred protesters yelled “Shame!” and “Get the f*ck out of here!” at the steady stream of masked agents in SUVs with out-of-state license plates coming and going.

An agent in a Kia Soul with Michigan plates blew kisses over his mask as he left the building. The masked passenger of a Hyundai Tucson with Illinois plates filmed protesters on his cell phone as they pulled into the gated compound.

Eric Lofdahl of St. Paul was there shaking a small copy of the U.S. Constitution at the agents driving by, as he had been for the past few days.

“The First Amendment, Fourth Amendment, 14th Amendment… these are things that this administration doesn’t care about,” Lofdahl said.

The atmosphere is often neighborly — people hand out slices of pizza, cups of hot coffee and handwarmers.

But the appearance of law enforcement have led to frequent skirmishes and arrests, including of a person dressed as a giraffe and another as a fox.

The federal government has delivered a forceful crackdown on protesters — who they call rioters. On Thursday, longtime civil rights attorney Nekima Levy Armstrong and two other activists were arrested for protesting during a church service where one of the pastors is an ICE field director. Attorney General Pam Bondi called it an attack on a place of worship.

The White House sent out a digitally doctored photo of Levy Armstrong that showed her crying and her skin tone a darker hue.

‘For us, it’s always been the safest state’

The federal incursion is activating residents who haven’t previously been very political as it infringes on their daily lives.

Ana Alarcon, a U.S. citizen, was at the laundromat early one Sunday morning with her kids when two ICE agents came in and started questioning her. Another time, she was leaving a Mexican grocery store with her husband, a permanent U.S. resident from Mexico, and saw ICE agents stopped in traffic, studying her license plate.

“You never think Minnesota would be what it’s like now,” Alarcon said. “For us, it’s always been the safest state.”

Her daughter turned 18 this month, but they didn’t have a big party because most of her friends didn’t want to leave home.

Alarcon now carries her passport with her all the time and doesn’t let her husband leave the house alone. He doesn’t speak fluent English, and she worries he won’t even get the chance to show his papers before being detained. Also, if there’s two of them, one will be able to record it on their phone.

“We’ve noticed that if there’s only one person in the car, the agents tend to take their phones or knock it out of their hands,” Alarcon said.

She doesn’t want to be mistaken for being afraid, however. Certainly not in front of a federal agent, because she has nothing to hide.

So, for the first time, she started going to protests.

“Being afraid … it’s like venom. It’s like a sickness,” Alarcon said. “We have to get out and not show them we’re not afraid.”

Reformer journalist Madison McVan contributed reporting and translation.

name: Litigation
title: Lawsuit challenges Trump ending Ethiopians' temporary legal status | Reuters
description:
Summary Trump administration accused of unconstitutional animus Biden administration extended temporary protected status due to ongoing conflicts BOSTON, Jan 23 (Reuters) - Immigrant rights advocates have filed a lawsuit seeking to block U.S. President Donald Trump's administration from ending temporary protections from deportation that had been granted to thousands of Ethiopians living in the United States.
Jumpstart your morning with the latest legal news delivered straight to your inbox from The Daily Docket newsletter.
Under federal law, TPS is available to people whose home countries have experienced natural disasters, armed conflicts or other extraordinary events.
Former Democratic President Joe Biden's administration granted Ethiopians already in the United States that status beginning in 2022, citing the need to protect citizens fleeing armed conflict in their home nation.
While that civil war formally ended later in 2022, the Biden administration extended TPS for Ethiopians in mid-2024, citing armed conflict in another region, Amhara, which is ongoing.
text:
Summary

Trump administration accused of unconstitutional animus

Biden administration extended temporary protected status due to ongoing conflicts

BOSTON, Jan 23 (Reuters) - Immigrant rights advocates have filed a lawsuit seeking to block U.S. President Donald Trump's administration from ending temporary protections from deportation that had been granted to thousands of Ethiopians living in the United States.

Three Ethiopian nationals, along with the non-profit African Communities Together, allege in a lawsuit, opens new tab filed in Boston federal court on Thursday that the U.S. Department of Homeland Security is unlawfully putting over 5,000 people at risk of losing their temporary protected status after February 13.

Jumpstart your morning with the latest legal news delivered straight to your inbox from The Daily Docket newsletter. Sign up here.

They say that while Ethiopia remains a country in a humanitarian crisis, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem unlawfully terminated the Ethiopians' legal status with just 60 days' notice based on an unconstitutional animus, or ill will, against non-white immigrants. Ethiopia's population is predominantly Black.

DHS did not respond to a request for comment.

SIMILAR LAWSUITS FILED FOR MIGRANTS FROM OTHER COUNTRIES

The case is the latest in a series of lawsuits challenging the Trump administration's efforts to curtail protections from deportation extended to citizens of numerous countries through grants of TPS.

Under federal law, TPS is available to people whose home countries have experienced natural disasters, armed conflicts or other extraordinary events. It provides eligible migrants with work authorization and temporary protection from deportation.

Numerous lawsuits have been filed challenging the administration's moves to end similar protections for nationals from countries, including Syria, Venezuela, Haiti, Nicaragua and South Sudan, leading to court rulings that have at times slowed or halted the Trump administration's efforts to strip migrants of their legal status.

The latest lawsuit was filed after DHS said on December 12 it was ending TPS for Ethiopia, saying conditions in the African nation no longer posed a serious threat to people returning safely to it and that TPS was "never meant to be a ticket to permanent residency."

Former Democratic President Joe Biden's administration granted Ethiopians already in the United States that status beginning in 2022, citing the need to protect citizens fleeing armed conflict in their home nation.

The Ethiopian military and allies, including troops from neighboring Eritrea, had been battling forces from the northern region of Tigray in a conflict that killed thousands and displaced millions of people.

While that civil war formally ended later in 2022, the Biden administration extended TPS for Ethiopians in mid-2024, citing armed conflict in another region, Amhara, which is ongoing.

Reporting by Nate Raymond in Boston, Editing by Alexia Garamfalvi, Rod Nickel

Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles., opens new tab

Nate Raymond reports on the federal judiciary and litigation. He can be reached at nate.raymond@thomsonreuters.com.

name: Policy
title: Nurses demand Congress abolish ICE, invest in health care
description:
National Nurses United, the nation’s largest union of registered nurses, provided the following response to the House passage of H.R.
The proposed FY26 Homeland Security Appropriations bill does nothing to rein in the abuse of power that we see every day in our streets.
Nurses demand the removal of immigration enforcement agents from communities, the abolition of ICE, and accountability for this administration’s crimes against all residents of the United States.
Immigrant patients are delaying care for fear of being apprehended, and ICE is failing to provide necessary health care to detainees as required by law.
NNU affiliates include California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee, DC Nurses Association, Michigan Nurses Association, Minnesota Nurses Association, and New York State Nurses Association.
text:
National Nurses United, the nation’s largest union of registered nurses, provided the following response to the House passage of H.R. 7148, the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2026, and H.R. 7147, the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2026:

“After a year of constant, unchecked violence and militarization of our neighborhoods by the Trump administration—including the murder of Renee Good and Keith Porter, and the horrible violence against children, women, the elderly, and immigrants—that has horrified the nation, it is unconscionable that Congress would send $10 billion in funding to continue terrorizing our communities. The proposed FY26 Homeland Security Appropriations bill does nothing to rein in the abuse of power that we see every day in our streets.

Nurses demand the removal of immigration enforcement agents from communities, the abolition of ICE, and accountability for this administration’s crimes against all residents of the United States.

Make no mistake, the terror we are experiencing is being subsidized by our own government and is leading to irreparable harm to the working-class. Workers are being kidnapped at their place of work and being ripped away from their families. Families are often losing their sole source of household income and are unable to cover housing costs, food, and basic needs as a result. Children with immigrant parents are being pulled out of school for fear they might be separated from their parents, or worse be attacked by ICE in their own schools. Immigrant patients are delaying care for fear of being apprehended, and ICE is failing to provide necessary health care to detainees as required by law.

Instead of funding armed secret police to terrorize our Black and brown, AAPI, and indigenous neighbors, Congress must focus on the investments that nurses and working people are demanding to make our society safer, healthier, and more just.

The small investments to health agencies fail to reverse the destruction of our public health agencies caused by the Republican-led Congress and Trump administration, through last year’s budget bill and Reduction In Force (RIF) plans.

This appropriations bill also fails to reverse the $1 trillion in cuts to Medicaid and other public health programs that will force patients to go without care and safety-net hospitals to close. It fails to extend the enhanced ACA subsidies needed to prevent huge hikes in premiums for millions of families. And ultimately, it fails to make the transformational reforms nurses and working people are demanding, in order to guarantee health care to every person in the United States free at the point of service.

Nurses know that our vision for a healthy society is possible and we will not stop fighting until it is a reality.”

National Nurses United is the largest and fastest-growing union and professional association of registered nurses in the United States with more than 225,000 members nationwide. NNU affiliates include California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee, DC Nurses Association, Michigan Nurses Association, Minnesota Nurses Association, and New York State Nurses Association.

name: Human Rights
title: Feds pull immigrants held in Cumberland County Jail as they send recent detainees out of state
authors: Emma Davis, Rose Lundy, Josh Keefe
description:
Unlike many other states, Maine doesn’t have a dedicated ICE facility, which means local jails are relied on for detentions.
As of Wednesday, Cumberland County Jail hadn’t had any new bookings this week for federal immigration detainees.
The majority of immigration detainees that had been held in Cumberland County Jail were not Maine residents and were not detained in Maine, according to attorneys providing legal assistance.
The Cumberland County Sheriff’s Office doesn’t have a direct contract with ICE but has had a contract with the U.S.
Under this contract, Cumberland County Jail is given a daily rate to house federal detainees, including people awaiting a hearing on their immigration status or deportation.
text:
The federal government has moved detained immigrants out of Maine’s largest jail, a marked shift after the jail had been a detention hub during President Donald Trump’s second term so far.

While this comes amid U.S. Immigrations and Customs Enforcement’s heightened activities in Maine, the people known to have been detained during the operation so far were not being held in local jails but instead sent out of state soon after apprehension.

“Folks are having issues with being able to locate their loved ones,” said Ruben Torres, advocacy and policy manager for the Maine Immigrant Rights Coalition.

Unlike many other states, Maine doesn’t have a dedicated ICE facility, which means local jails are relied on for detentions.

On Thursday, The University of Maine’s School of Law’s Refugee and Human Rights Clinic, which has helped provide legal support to more than 300 people held in the county jail during Trump’s second term, began receiving frantic calls from detainees telling their counsel they were being moved.

Anna Welch, the founding director of the clinic, has heard from jail staff that there are no longer any immigration detainees in the facility as of Friday morning, though one person the clinic has helped is still showing up as in the facility, according to ICE’s detainee locator.

Based on that locator, people have since been sent to the Federal Correctional Institution in Berlin, New Hampshire; the Donald W. Wyatt Detention Facility in Rhode Island and the Plymouth County Correctional Facility in Massachusetts. But the locations for the majority of women removed from the jail are not yet clear, and Welch said they may be sent to Louisiana, based on conversations her co-counsel has had with detainees.

This is not the first time these people have been moved, as Welch and other attorneys said the majority of those that had been in the jail had not been apprehended in Maine and were instead moved from other facilities.

U.S. Department of Homeland Security, ICE and Cumberland County Jail did not immediately respond to requests for comment about the removal of people from the jail nor where the federal government is otherwise holding people detained during its Maine operation.

The abrupt removal from the facility comes after Cumberland County Sheriff Kevin Joyce publicly questioned on Thursday the agency’s priorities after ICE detained one of his corrections officer recruits. Joyce said the recruit had a “squeaky clean record.”

Unclear where new detainees are being held

Since the Trump administration launched its operation in Maine on Tuesday, local organizers and legal groups have tried to gather details about who has been taken and where they’re being sent, while Gov. Janet Mills and other Democratic officials are demanding transparency from the Trump administration, which has not been communicating with Maine leaders and shared few details of its plans.

With sparse information about who has been detained overall, and up to 48 hours for detainees to be entered into the tracking system, little is known about people’s whereabouts.

As of Wednesday, Cumberland County Jail hadn’t had any new bookings this week for federal immigration detainees. Before they were moved out, there had been 64 immigration detainees in the facility, with nine total new bookings in January.

Cumberland and Androscoggin County, which includes Lewiston, are the areas that have had the most ICE activity so far, based on reports verified by community organizers, though federal agents have also been seen elsewhere in recent days.

Androscoggin County Jail has only had one person with immigration related charges booked this week, but that person was brought in on Tuesday by the Lewiston Police Department on local charges. Police told the jail upon arrival that the person also had a federal detainer, meaning he’ll be held for ICE if he makes bail.

Two Bridges Regional Jail in Bath has held the second-most immigration detainees throughout Trump’s second term, but it’s also had no new immigration-related bookings since the heightened operations in Maine, intake supervisor Corporal Aaron Smith said.

The facility has five ICE detainees, but they’ve been there for an average of 301 days, with the shortest length of time being 272 days and the longest being 318 days, Smith said. They were all transferred to Two Bridges from other facilities, so it is unclear how long they’ve been in detention overall.

A pattern of moving immigrant detainees

The Immigrant Legal Advocacy Project, Maine’s only statewide immigration legal services organization, expects people already out of state could be moved again to more remote detention facilities. That’s the pattern that has emerged out of Minnesota. In that case often to a facility in Texas and more recently, in some cases, then to New Mexico.

Down South is where the largest detention facilities are. That was the case even before the Trump administration pumped more money into them through the spending bill passed in the summer.

It’s also more difficult to get attorneys to those sprawling, more remote areas, said Sarah Mehta, deputy director of policy and government affairs for immigration at the American Civil Liberties Union.

In Maine, someone was moved out of state this week hours before a federal judge had ordered ICE not to do so.

On Tuesday, ICE detained Yanick Joao Carneiro of Portland, an asylum seeker from Angola, at a routine immigration check-in without a warrant, according to the petition filed by his lawyer.

U.S. District Court Judge Stacey Neumann ordered ICE to explain why they arrested him. Instead, Assistant U.S. Attorney James Concannon argued in his filing that Neumann no longer had the authority to rule on Carneiro’s case because he’s in Massachusetts.

The majority of immigration detainees that had been held in Cumberland County Jail were not Maine residents and were not detained in Maine, according to attorneys providing legal assistance. Jail records don’t provide that insight, though, as records only indicate the overall agency that’s the arresting body.

But, according to attorneys, most appear to be transferred to the facility from out of state, and they are often quickly transferred out, too.

Federal authorities may move people for any number of reasons — space, staffing — but legal experts say regardless of intent, this movement creates chaos and makes it more difficult for legal counsel to advocate for their clients and for families to keep in touch.

The use of Cumberland County Jail to aid Trump’s mass deportation agenda became clear in the spring when public records requested revealed the facility had increased detentions for federal immigration authorities.

The jail has since faced mounting pressure from community members to end its contract that permits such detentions. The Cumberland County Sheriff’s Office doesn’t have a direct contract with ICE but has had a contract with the U.S. Marshal Service since July 2010. Under this contract, Cumberland County Jail is given a daily rate to house federal detainees, including people awaiting a hearing on their immigration status or deportation.

name: Policy
title: Mass anti-immigration enforcement protests planned in Minnesota - The Hill
description:
“We really, really want ICE to leave Minnesota, and they’re not going to leave Minnesota unless there’s a ton of pressure on them,” Kate Havelin, a member of Indivisible Twin Cities, one of the groups behind the demonstration, told The Associated Press.
The protesters are demanding that ICE leave Minnesota immediately, that Ross is held “legally accountable” and that federal funding to ICE is halted.
Vice President Vance visited Minneapolis on Thursday, acknowledging ICE had made some “mistakes” in how it has handled immigration enforcement in the city.
Havelin said Minnesotans would use their expertise in dealing with winter weather to face the challenge presented by ICE.
“And what’s happening with ICE in our community, in our state, means that we can’t respond as business as usual.”
text:
Various groups opposed to the Trump administration’s aggressive operations targeting immigrants in Minnesota are planning mass demonstrations and an “economic blackout” on Friday in an attempt to pressure Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers to leave the state.

Organizers from more than 100 groups — including labor unions, progressive organizations and religious groups — urged Minnesotans to skip school and work on Friday and avoid shopping to participate in 2 p.m. marches on what they are calling “ICE Out of Minnesota Day of Truth & Freedom.” Temperatures are forecast to hover around 0 degrees throughout the afternoon.

“We really, really want ICE to leave Minnesota, and they’re not going to leave Minnesota unless there’s a ton of pressure on them,” Kate Havelin, a member of Indivisible Twin Cities, one of the groups behind the demonstration, told The Associated Press. “They shouldn’t be roaming any streets in our country just the way they are now.”

Anti-ICE protests have swept across Minnesota in recent weeks in response to the shooting of Renee Good, a 37-year-old mother who was killed by an ICE officer in Minneapolis earlier this month. Good was shot three times and grazed by a fourth bullet, according to a private autopsy report released Wednesday. The Trump administration argues the officer, Jonathan Ross, was acting in self-defense.

The protesters are demanding that ICE leave Minnesota immediately, that Ross is held “legally accountable” and that federal funding to ICE is halted. They’re also demanding that ICE be investigated for “human and Constitutional violations of Americans and our neighbors.”

“It is time to suspend the normal order of business to demand immediate cessation of ICE actions in MN, accountability for federal agents who have caused loss of life and abuse to Minnesota residents and call for Congress to immediately intervene,” the website for the protest states.

Tensions between ICE and protesters in Minnesota continued to escalate this week after a group of protesters interrupted a church service over the weekend, targeting a pastor who also holds a senior position in the regional ICE office.

Attorney General Pam Bondi announced Thursday that federal agents arrested Nekima Levy Armstrong, a prominent attorney and one of the alleged leaders of the protest.

ICE officers have faced renewed criticism for detaining a 5-year-old boy and his father in Minnesota after the boy had just returned from preschool.

Vice President Vance visited Minneapolis on Thursday, acknowledging ICE had made some “mistakes” in how it has handled immigration enforcement in the city. But he said the main way to avoid situations with ICE is for Democrats to cooperate with the administration.

The National Weather Service has reported dangerously cold weather in Minneapolis on Friday. Havelin said Minnesotans would use their expertise in dealing with winter weather to face the challenge presented by ICE.

“Minnesotans understand that when we’re in a snow emergency … we all have to respond and it makes us do things differently,” Havelin told the AP. “And what’s happening with ICE in our community, in our state, means that we can’t respond as business as usual.”

name: Human Rights
title: The 2026 Legislative Session: Creating A Firewall for Freedom in New Mexico
description:
As we approach the 2026 legislative session, our nation is facing unprecedented threats to our fundamental freedoms.
That same unchecked system is also inflicting harm inside detention centers— including right here in New Mexico.
For years, conditions in New Mexico’s three immigration detention centers have been dangerous and dehumanizing and the current administration has only intensified those risks.
While New Mexico cannot directly regulate ICE, we can refuse to enable a system that violates human rights and due process.
Everyone in New Mexico deserves to live in safe communities, and we have the ability to make real progress on safety this session.
text:
As we approach the 2026 legislative session, our nation is facing unprecedented threats to our fundamental freedoms. For the past year, President Trump has tested every limit and abused every power to silence dissent, terrorize immigrants, unleash violence and chaos in our cities and neighborhoods, and expand surveillance in ways that threaten the safety of millions.

But we aren’t powerless against these attacks. This legislative session, the ACLU of New Mexico will fight —alongside our partners and community activists— to safeguard hard-fought protections New Mexico leaders have already won and to pass new, urgent bills that will shield New Mexicans’ from the Trump administration’s most dangerous attacks.

Here are the bills we’re championing—and those we’ll fight against.

That same unchecked system is also inflicting harm inside detention centers— including right here in New Mexico. For years, conditions in New Mexico’s three immigration detention centers have been dangerous and dehumanizing and the current administration has only intensified those risks. People held in detention facilities in Torrance, Cibola, and Otero counties have reported abysmal conditions like rotten food, sewage water in their cells, and the misuse of solitary confinement. Three people have also died in these facilities in recent years— a pattern reflected across the country in a rising death toll that reached its highest point in more than two decades last year.

While New Mexico cannot directly regulate ICE, we can refuse to enable a system that violates human rights and due process. At least eight other states have already passed laws limiting collaboration with ICE.

The New Mexico Immigrant Safety Act would do exactly that. It would bar state and local governments from entering into agreements to detain people for federal immigration violations, remove New Mexico from the business of mass deportation, and end the leasing of public land for immigration detention.

With detention conditions deteriorating and abuses mounting across the country, we’re standing with immigrant rights advocates to demand the passage of this urgent bill in New Mexico.

Law enforcement in New Mexico collects huge amounts of data on us through surveillance technology, including cameras known as automatic license plate readers (ALPRs). These devices, mounted on police cars or on objects like road signs and bridges, use high‑speed cameras to photograph thousands of plates per minute—creating a detailed record of where we drive.

While this technology has legitimate law enforcement uses and can help solve crimes, sharing this data with out‑of‑state or federal authorities carries serious risks. It has been used to track immigrant community members, people seeking abortion care, and activists. A recent ACLU-NM public records request showed that New Mexico ALPR cameras have been accessed thousands of times by out-of- state authorities for immigration enforcement, and at least once by Texas authorities to track a woman under criminal investigation for seeking abortion care.

New Mexico should join the growing number of states and cities that have enacted common-sense limits on how ALRP data can be used and shared.

The Driver Privacy and Safety Act would prohibit data sharing for purposes that violate New Mexico values, while ensuring law enforcement can continue using ALPRs for legitimate investigations. Passing this bill is critical to ensure outside authorities can’t turn our surveillance tools against us to target our families and communities.

Tech companies constantly harvest and sell personal data far beyond shopping preferences. Information about our immigration status, gender identity, or whether we’ve accessed reproductive healthcare can be purchased by anyone — including out‑of‑state law enforcement and anti‑LGBTQ+ politicians. Every time we post on social media or search the web, online service providers retain that information and may share it with the government. For non‑citizens, this data is already being used in visa screenings and could soon be used for other international entry decisions. Even something as simple as entering “Planned Parenthood” into Google Maps becomes part of a data trail that can be bought and weaponized.

Under an administration that is terrorizing immigrants, targeting protestors and critics, and dismantling reproductive and LGBTQ rights it is even more crucial that New Mexico strengthen its privacy protections.

CHISPA would require for‑profit companies serving New Mexicans to collect only the data that is necessary to provide the service requested, and to obtain explicit consent before collecting, processing, or sharing anything more—an opt‑in standard far stronger than the typical opt‑out model. Critically, the bill has teeth by giving individuals the right to sue when their privacy is violated. We’ll be working alongside the NM CHISPA coalition to pass this bill and ensure that New Mexicans — not corporations or hostile governments — control their own data.

Everyone in New Mexico deserves to live in safe communities, and we have the ability to make real progress on safety this session. What we know from experience and research is that the safest communities are those where everyone is housed, where everyone can access the healthcare they need voluntarily, and where everyone has access to quality jobs and education. Investments in these areas are investments in public safety.

This year, with our partners in the All Safe New Mexico coalition, we’re asking the legislature to make significant investments in housing services so that New Mexicans can build and maintain lasting stability in their lives. We’re also asking legislators to continue leading the country on harm reduction and a public‑health approach to substance use by studying overdose prevention centers and ensuring that people can access medication‑assisted treatment in their communities.

At the same time, we must reject proposals that expand mass incarceration or make it easier to involuntarily commit people who are unhoused—the very approach President Trump advanced in his dangerous executive order last year. Policies that increase sentences, create new crimes, target youth, or push people into locked institutions won’t make us safer. They will deepen the challenges our communities have faced for years.

We’re advocating for common‑sense, root‑cause solutions that strengthen our communities and promote real safety, not policies that criminalize people.

name: Human Rights
outlet: KYMN Radio · Northfield, MN · AM 1080 & FM 95.1
title: Northfield Leaders Reaffirm Limits on Local Role in Immigration Enforcement - KYMN Radio
description:
By Rich Larson, KYMN News Northfield city leaders are emphasizing their commitment to constitutional principles, public safety, and community trust as federal immigration enforcement actions continue to spark fear and disruption across Minnesota.
The statement, now posted on the city’s website, outlines Northfield’s values, clarifies the city’s limited role in federal immigration enforcement, and directs residents to local resources.
While emphasizing that cities do not control federal immigration policy, Zweifel said Northfield has a responsibility to speak clearly about its values and expectations.
Martig, who oversees the police department, said there has historically been limited cooperation with federal immigration authorities in cases involving serious crimes, but current conditions are different.
Zweifel’s statement calls on federal immigration officials to uphold due process, avoid intimidation, respect free speech, and operate transparently.
text:
By Rich Larson, KYMN News

Northfield city leaders are emphasizing their commitment to constitutional principles, public safety, and community trust as federal immigration enforcement actions continue to spark fear and disruption across Minnesota.

On Tuesday night, during the regular City Council meeting, Mayor Erica Zweifel read a prepared statement addressing concerns raised by residents about Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) activity both locally and statewide. The statement, now posted on the city’s website, outlines Northfield’s values, clarifies the city’s limited role in federal immigration enforcement, and directs residents to local resources.

The statement, the full text of which can be read here, acknowledges the fear and uncertainty expressed by families, students, businesses, and faith communities. While emphasizing that cities do not control federal immigration policy, Zweifel said Northfield has a responsibility to speak clearly about its values and expectations.

Zweifel referenced the city’s vision of being “open, safe, and welcoming,” and noted that city council members and local officials are sworn to uphold the U.S. Constitution. She also publicly recognized Police Chief Jeff Schroepfer and the Northfield Police Department, stressing that local police do not enforce federal immigration law and remain focused on professionalism, de-escalation, and serving the entire community.

“They’re stuck between a rock and a hard place,” she said.

City Administrator Ben Martig echoed those concerns, describing both operational and community impacts stemming from current ICE tactics. Martig, who oversees the police department, said there has historically been limited cooperation with federal immigration authorities in cases involving serious crimes, but current conditions are different.

He cited a recent incident reported by Brooklyn Park’s police chief involving armed ICE agents stopping an off-duty officer as an example of escalating concerns, and he said just the threat of aggressive ICE situations has already affected the city.

“As we’ve talked about, there’s been a long history of cooperation with immigration enforcement and in particular around the more serious crimes that would be occurring than trying to do enforcement with those limited individuals where that comes into play. We’re in a different world right now where there’s no communication happening, a lot of questionable use of force that we’ve observed, tactics that are happening. And so that’s really caused an impact.”

According to Martig, the situation is straining city operations, diverting staff time toward communications and crisis response, and affecting local service providers, schools, and the economy.

Zweifel’s statement calls on federal immigration officials to uphold due process, avoid intimidation, respect free speech, and operate transparently. She also urged Minnesota’s elected leaders to affirm peace and dignity and support accountability where concerns arise.

The city has expanded access to immigration-related information through its website, including recorded presentations by immigration attorneys, resources curated by the Human Rights Commission, and links to community partners such as the Community Action Center.

In her statement, the Mayor said that Northfield remains committed to the common good of all who live, learn, work, worship, and do business here, and added that city leaders will continue to lead “with care, clarity, and a steadfast commitment to our community.”

name: Human Rights
title: U.N. human rights chief slams White House over immigration crackdown tactics
authors: Mike Glenn, The Washington Times https:, www.washingtontimes.com
description:
Speaking at a conference in Geneva, Mr. Turk said he was astounded by the acts of “now-routine abuse and denigration” carried out by U.S. immigration officials.
Mr. Turk acknowledged that sovereign nations have the authority to establish migration policies but said they must be done in accordance with the law.
Mr. Turk appeared to be referring to the Jan. 7 fatal shooting of Renee Good, 37, by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Jonathan Ross.
Trump administration officials said the ICE agent acted in self-defense because she was driving toward him during an anti-immigration protest in Minneapolis.
Mr. Turk said U.S. history has been shaped by the contributions that migrants have made.
text:
Volker Turk, the U.N.’s commissioner for human rights, on Friday accused the Trump administration of launching immigration raids that don’t respect the due process rights of migrants and refugees and have resulted in violent detentions at hospitals, courthouses and houses of worship.

Speaking at a conference in Geneva, Mr. Turk said he was astounded by the acts of “now-routine abuse and denigration” carried out by U.S. immigration officials.

“Where is the concern for their dignity and our common humanity?” the Austrian said. “Those who dare to speak up or protest peacefully against heavy-handed immigration raids are vilified and threatened by officials and, on occasion, subject to arbitrary violence themselves.”

The Trump administration said its rounding up of illegal immigrants has helped secure the U.S.-Mexico border and resulted in the arrest and deportation of hundreds of thousands of criminal migrants, including drug traffickers, murderers, rapists and gang members.

The Washington Times reached out to the White House for comment.

Mr. Turk acknowledged that sovereign nations have the authority to establish migration policies but said they must be done in accordance with the law.

“Adhering to due process is crucial to the legality and legitimacy of any policy,” he said. “If these principles are not followed, it will more broadly erode public trust, diminish legal certainty, weaken institutional legitimacy and violate individuals’ rights.”

Mr. Turk also denounced what he called unnecessary or disproportionate enforcement operations.

“Under international law, the intentional use of lethal force is only permissible as a measure of last resort against an individual representing an imminent threat to life,” he said.

Mr. Turk appeared to be referring to the Jan. 7 fatal shooting of Renee Good, 37, by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Jonathan Ross.

Trump administration officials said the ICE agent acted in self-defense because she was driving toward him during an anti-immigration protest in Minneapolis. Local officials in Minnesota have challenged the federal government’s narrative of what happened, saying Good was steering away from Mr. Ross when she was shot.

Mr. Turk said U.S. history has been shaped by the contributions that migrants have made.

“Demonizing migrants and refugees collectively as criminals, threats or burdens on society — based on their origin, nationality or migration status — is inhumane, wrong, and goes against the very fabric and foundation of the nation,” he said.
